text:
(1)
Feast of Our Lady of Mt. Carmel: Vendor of candy and delicacies, with horse and wagon, on 116th Street between First and Second Avenues.

July 15, 1924.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
Vendors of candy and delicacies, stand on Pleasant Avenue.

July 16, 1924.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
Vendor of clams, with pushcart, Pleasant Avenue at N.W. corner of 114th Street. Other vendors are seen in the background; and the Avenue is gaily decorated.

July 16, 1924.

P. L. Sperr
title: Feast of Our Lady of Mount Carmel.

title: Feast of Our Lady of Mount Carmel.

text:
(1) Feast of Our Lady of Mt. Carmel: Fortune-teller, with a parrot, 115th Street east of Pleasant Avenue. The gas-tank belongs to the Standard Gas Light Company, it is later to be demolished. July 16, 1925.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) Another fortune-teller and his parrot receive the respectful attention of three small children on East 116th Street, between First and Second Avenues. July 16, 1925.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) Two fortune-tellers in the crowd on a street near Jefferson Park. July 16, 1925.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Feast of Our Lady of Mount Carmel.

text:
341-349 East 116th Street, west of the N.W. corner of First Ave. Nos. 343-347 is the East Harlem Health Center, (Department of Health). These buildings were formerly occupied by the Red Cross.

July 16, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Feast of St. Anthony of Padua, 1929, No. 1. The parade held Saturday before Labor Day, shown turning west on 116th Street from First Avenue, at the N.W. corner. This section bears a religious society banner, flanked by the American and Italian flags.

The Bank of America, a branch of which is shown here, will in a little over two years be consolidated with the National City Bank.
August 31, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
No. 2. The same; the advance guard of the parade, bearing the statue of St. Anthony, and followed by the band, is proceeding
west on 116th Street from First Avenue.
August 31, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

(3)
No. 3. 106th Street east from First Avenue, showing the tower which is to be paraded on 106th Street on Labor Day, as usual. This year it is surmounted by a figure of Mary of the Immaculate Conception.
August 31, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
title: Feast of Saint Anthony of Padua.

text:
First Avenue, west side, north from 116th Street. The truck in the foreground contains pilgrims to the annual Feast of Our Lady of Mt. Carmel. Additional pictures of this feast will be found under the heading "Festivals".

July 16, 1935.

P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

Italian chesses and dairy products for sale at 2265 First Ave.

July 16, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

The same; a closer view.

July 16, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

The same; another view; showing an unusual shape of cheese.

July 16, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.
